Introduction

Motivation

docs/introduction/Motivation.html.title: 1.1. Motivation
docs/introduction/Motivation.html.body:
Motivation
Within React applications, I frequently want to share and update some state without having to pass it down the whole component tree.
Usually you would go with something like Redux or MobX, but I dislike the idea to use those for small things like showing/hiding a modal. In general, I prefer using those only for business logic.
With React's new Context API, we get an encapsulated way to share state throughout the whole child component tree without having to pass it down and since React 16.3 it even ships a lightweight render-props based component API instead of using the old declarative API.

docs/introduction/How.html.title: 1.2. How It Works
docs/introduction/How.html.body:
How It Works
Alveron is entirely built on React's build-in Context API.
Creating a new store instance using createStore will use React's createContext to create a local context store returning two components: Provider and Consumer.
Alveron wraps those components in order to automatically bind the model, actions and effects to its local React state.

docs/introduction/Caveats.html.title: 1.3. Caveats
docs/introduction/Caveats.html.body:
Caveats
1. Unique Store Instances
createStore doesn't actually create a store directly, but rather create a factory by providing the Provider component.
Every Provider component therefore manages its own state object, that is derived from the store model and the passed initialState.
Thus, having multiple Provider will lead to multiple store instances that both have separate state. The Consumer component will always interact with the closest wrapping Provider.
In order to have a single global store instance, wrap your root component with the Provider component and use the Consumer whereever you'd like to access that global store.

docs/introduction/Comparison.html.title: 1.4. Comparison
docs/introduction/Comparison.html.body:
Comparison
This section should help to understand the differences to other (React based) state management libraries.
Redux

Talking about Redux, we're actually refering to its React bindings (react-redux) as alveron is React-only anyways.

Constate

docs/introduction/Examples.html.title: 1.6. Examples
docs/introduction/Examples.html.body:
Examples

Counter
TodoList
Async API

Counter
The first example is a super basic counter.
One can find the source code under examples/Counter.
You will also find a guide how to run the example.

It covers:

Model
Actions
Actions with Payload
Delayed Actions using Effects

TodoList
A TodoList is a common example to showcase basic state management.
One can find the source code under examples/TodoList.
You will also find a guide how to run the example.

It covers:

Model
Actions
Actions with Payload
Immutable Array Updates
State Selection

Async API
This example is a bit more advanced as it included fetching data from an actual REST API.
One can find the source code under examples/AsyncAPI.
You will also find a guide how to run the example.

It covers:

Model
Actions
Actions with Payload
Effects
Data Fetching using Effects

docs/concepts/Model.html.title: 2.1. Model
docs/concepts/Model.html.body:
Model
The model describes the initial state of a store.
It can be composed of any shape and can be filled with some default data before any action is called yet.
const Model: any = any

docs/concepts/Actions.html.title: 2.2. Actions
docs/concepts/Actions.html.body:
Actions
Actions are used to update the state in a functional way.
They are so called reducers that receive both the current state and some payload and return the new state.
const Action: any = (previousState: any, ...payload) => newState

While it doesn't enforce any restrictions on how to calculate the new state, here are some recommendations:

Do not mutate the current state, but rather use immutable data structures
Ensure that all actions are pure functions
All actions should have a single responsibility

Pure Functions
A pure function should:

always return the same output for given input
not manipulate the input
not cause side effects (e.g. API calls)

Unidirectional Data Flow
Given that the only way to update the state is calling a action, we always have an unidirectional data flow.
Calling actions will automatically update the state and rerender all consuming components to ensure predictable and up-to-date output.

docs/concepts/Effects.html.title: 2.3. Effects
docs/concepts/Effects.html.body:
Effects
Apart from actions, there is another way to update the state: (side) effects.
Effects do not actually update the state directly, but rather call an equivalent action once resolved.
const Effect: void = (actions: Object, ...payload) => {}

They're used for asynchronous operations such as API requests or delayed calls.
For example, sending an API request to get some user data will not immediately yield an answer. The server must first receive the call, process it and send an answer over the network which unfortunately takes some time.
Yet we learned, that actions shouldn't cause side effects and be predictable in their output. That's where effects fill the gap. When an effect is called, it e.g. sends the API requests, waits for the answer, and then calls an action with the received data once.

docs/concepts/Middleware.html.title: 2.4. Middleware
docs/concepts/Middleware.html.body:
Middleware

The Middleware API is not yet finished as the Proposal needs to be finalized first.

docs/API.html.title: 4. API Reference
docs/API.html.body:
API Reference

createStore
Provider
Consumer
Wrapper

docs/api/createStore.html.title: 4.1. createStore
docs/api/createStore.html.body:
createStore
The only public API as of today.
It creates a new store instance that provides both Provider and Consumer components as well as a shorthand Wrapper component to interact with the store.
It accepts a single options object, that allows the following options.
Options



Argument
Type
Description




actions
(Object?)
A map of actions where the key represents the action name and the value represents the action reducer


effects
(Object?)
A map of effects where the key represents the effect name and the value represents the updater


model
(any?)
The default model reflecting the initial state shape



Returns
(Object) an object containing the Provider, Consumer and Wrapper components. 
Example
import { createStore } from 'alveron'

const model = 0
const actions = {
  increment: state => state + 1,
  decrement: state => state - 1
}

const { Provider, Consumer, Wrapper } = createStore({
  actions,
  model
})
